title: Mum has bleach thrown at her by racists making monkey noises
text:
Reem Fahad believes she was targeted by racists inspired by hooligans at the Bulgarian v England match (Picture: Mercury)

A young mum had bleach thrown at her as she walked home by racists chanting monkey noises at her.

Reem Fahad, 24, believes her attackers were inspired by racist football hooligans at the England v Bulgaria match earlier this week.

The support-worker, who is mixed race, was walking along a main road in Horwich, Bolton, at around 1.30pm on Tuesday – the day after the match – when the bleach was thrown at her from a passing car.

She had headphones in and was looking at her phone for Christmas presents for her son King, three, so she didn’t see the small black car approach.

The first she noticed something was wrong was when her hair and clothes were suddenly wet.

Reem said she heard the men inside the car shouting monkey noises at her before they sped away, the same noises racist Bulgarian fans made that almost saw Monday night’s match called off.

Manchester-born Reem, who was on her way to help a patient with dementia, said: ‘I thought it was acid at first but it didn’t burn through straight away.

‘It looked like young white lads in the car and they were making money noises at me – it was disgusting.

‘If my little boy had been there he would have been right in the line of the window where the lads threw the bleach and it might have got him.

Reem said she is thankful she was not with her young son King at the time of the attack (Picture: Mercury) ‘I presume it’s the football that’s kicked all this off and I think that alcohol was involved because the lads were loud, it’s ridiculous.’

Reem still met up with her client before calling the police to report the incident an hour later.

By this point, she said the bleach had stained through her clothing and work uniform and began to irritate her skin, causing itching and redness.

She said: ‘I would have confronted the men if I could have – it won’t stop me from going to work.

‘I grew up in Manchester in the 90s so I have experienced racism pretty much all my life and I think that this attack just goes to show that racism hasn’t gone away, it’s still there.

‘How can I teach my son to be proud and understanding when this is the ignorance people still have?’

Racist fans at the England match earlier this week (Picture: ITV)

Greater Manchester Police took Reem’s clothes for testing and are appealing for witnesses to get in touch.

The force confirmed the incident is believed to be a racially motivated attack.

Reem said: ‘I’m not scared but I don’t want it to happen to anyone else, so I hope these people are found as soon as possible.

‘I feel sorry for the ignorance and lack of education these men have and I hope nobody ever singles them out for the colour of their skin.

‘I’ve never experienced racism in Horwich before but I’ve been inundated with messages and I really appreciate the support.

‘It’s angered a lot of people, including my partner, but I don’t want it to become a fight. I want to fight hate with love and understanding.’
